channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Delays Plans for Mass Production of Self-Driving Cars After Accident
item.description: After years of planning for cars that would let drivers take their hands off the wheel and eyes off the road, China’s regulators have become more cautious.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.category: Guangzhou Xiaopeng Motors Technology Co Ltd (Xpeng Motors)
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Changan Automobile assembly line in May. Changan is one of only two automakers approved to conduct limited testing of self-driving taxis.

item.title: Turmoil at CBS News After Bari Weiss Pulls a ‘60 Minutes’ Segment
item.description: Several veteran correspondents questioned how Ms. Weiss, the new CBS News editor in chief, had handled the segment, after she defended her decision on a call with the newsroom.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Manhattan studios of CBS News, whose editor in chief, Bari Weiss, spoke to the newsroom on Monday about a “60 Minutes” segment she had postponed. “I held that story because it was not ready,” she said.

item.title: Epstein Victims Ask Congress to Ensure Justice Dept. Releases All Files
item.description: More than a dozen women called for congressional hearings to ensure that the Justice Department is fully complying with the Epstein Files Transparency Act.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Annabelle Gordon/Reuters
item.media:description: Jess Michaels at a news conference in November. She was among the women who signed the letter released Monday.

item.title: Did Charlie Javice’s 147-Member Legal Team Expense $529 in Gummy Bears?
item.description: JPMorgan has had to pay tens of millions in legal costs for the convicted fraudster. It wants the public to see a newly unredacted list of itemized expenses.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon/Reuters
item.media:description: Charlie Javice was found guilty of fraud in September. She has spent more than $70 million so far on her legal defense.

item.title: Agriculture Department Sheds a Fifth of Its Workers
item.description: From January to June, more than 20,000 employees out of more than 110,000 left the agency, according to a report by the agency’s inspector general.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Agriculture Department in Washington.

item.title: How U.S. Defense Industry Dodged a Rare-Earth Shortage After China’s Curbs
item.description: America’s ability to make precision-guided missiles was threatened during Trump’s tariff war. But experienced players have rescued the supply chain, for now.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display of Raytheon missiles including a Tomahawk, center, which uses magnets made with samarium, a rare earth.

item.title: Larry Ellison Personally Guarantees Paramount Bid for Warner Bros.
item.description: Mr. Ellison’s personal guarantee is meant to address concerns that the Warner Bros. Discovery’s board had expressed about Paramount’s original offer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch

item.title: China Vanke Gets Temporary Lifeline to Prevent Debt Default
item.description: Bondholders for one of China’s biggest real estate developers extended a grace period to negotiate a delayed repayment of a $285 million bond issue.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Residential buildings under construction by China Vanke, a real estate developer, in Hangzhou, last year.

item.title: Riding a High, Deal Makers Grow Bullish on 2026
item.description: It was a comeback year for I.P.O.s. and mergers and acquisitions. Wall Street is optimistic that the winning streak will continue.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: I.P.O.s had a big comeback in 2025. Figma, the design software maker, was among those to make a splashy entry in the public market.

item.title: The Economy Survived 2025, But Many Americans Are Reeling
item.description: A feared recession didn’t materialize, but unemployment rose, wage growth slowed and affordability challenges are mounting.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Colby Smith
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:credit: Ricardo Rey

item.title: Uber Clears Violent Felons to Drive
item.description: Our reporter, Emily Steel, found that in many states, Uber’s guidelines allow people with serious criminal convictions to drive, as long as those convictions are more than seven years old. Some of those drivers have gone on to sexually assault or harass passengers.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel, Christina Shaman, Zach Caldwell, David Jouppi and Thomas Trudeau

item.title: Uber Cleared Violent Felons to Drive. Passengers Accused Them of Rape.
item.description: The ride-hailing giant’s background check process was intended to speed drivers onto its network while keeping costs down, internal documents show.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel and Erin Schaff

item.title: Help Us Report on Sexual Assault During Uber and Lyft Rides
item.description: For several months, we have been investigating sexual violence during Uber and Lyft rides, which is far more pervasive than publicly disclosed. Now, we need your help.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel

item.title: ’60 Minutes’ Pulls Segment on Venezuelans Deported by Trump Administration, Drawing Criticism
item.description: Sharyn Alfonsi, a “60 Minutes” correspondent, criticized the network’s decision to remove her reporting from Sunday’s edition of the show.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Terrorism Confinement Center, known as CECOT, in Tecoluca, El Salvador, in March.

item.title: In a First, a Wheelchair User Joins a Short Flight to Space
item.description: A paraplegic engineer was part of a crew that made a suborbital journey on a spacecraft operated by Jeff Bezos’ private company, Blue Origin.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Blue Origin, via Reuters

item.title: ‘Avatar’ Sequel Is Neither Fire Nor Ash at North American Box Office
item.description: “Avatar: Fire and Ash” took in $88 million over the weekend, a sizable No. 1 total that nonetheless fell 34 percent behind the opening for its franchise predecessor.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: 20th Century Studios
item.media:description: James Cameron’s third “Avatar” movie debuted to an estimated $345 million worldwide.

item.title: How Many Toys Will Parents Buy for Their Kids This Christmas?
item.description: Ynon Kreiz, the chief executive of Mattel, believes consumers squeezed by tariffs and inflation will cut back on other things before they skimp on Barbies and Hot Wheels.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ynon Kreiz has run Mattel since 2018.

item.title: When Something Goes Wrong With Your Flight, These People Take Charge
item.description: Inside a tornado-hardened office in Texas, 1,700 American Airlines employees manage the carrier’s operations, responding to bad weather, plane trouble and ailing passengers.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Desiree Rios
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Sikh Truckers Found Refuge In Trucking Until The Trump Administration’s Crackdown
item.description: Two high-profile crashes and a Trump administration crackdown have brought worry, and wariness, to the community.
item.dc:creator: Kurtis Lee

item.title: NYC Holiday Markets Offer Profit and Peril for Small-Business Owners
item.description: The festive fairs have become vital to the success of many artists and retailers. But the booths are expensive, and the payoffs aren’t guaranteed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag and Natalie Keyssar
item.media:description: The Union Square market, one of four major holiday fairs in Manhattan.

item.title: A Neighborhood in India Fears Being Blamed for a Distant Atrocity
item.description: The attacker killed at last week’s Hanukkah celebration in Australia came from a Muslim area whose residents have long gone abroad to seek better lives.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Toli Chowki, an area of the southern Indian city of Hyderabad with many Muslim residents, has been in an unwelcome spotlight in recent days.

item.title: Power Restored for Most of San Francisco After Widespread Outage
item.description: The hourslong outage affected nearly a third of the city and forced the closure of transit stations. Service was restored for most customers late Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Alessandro Marazzi Sassoon
item.media:credit: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press
item.media:description: A Waymo vehicle idling at an intersection with no operating traffic lights on Saturday.

item.title: Robert Mnuchin, Stock Trader Turned Art Dealer, Dies at 92
item.description: A major player in the block-trading boom, he left Wall Street for the art world, winning a Jeff Koons sculpture at auction for $91 million in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Matt Phillips
item.media:credit: David Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Mnuchin at Mnuchin Gallery in 2019. “I’ve loved art for so long, I was looking for a way to become even more involved,” he told The New York Times in 1992 after opening his first gallery, C&M Arts.

item.title: From A.I. to Tariffs, 14 Charts That Explain 2025
item.description: President Trump’s trade policy, inflation and climbing stock prices shaped business and the economy this year.
item.dc:creator: Christine Zhang
item.media:credit: Mike Haddad

item.title: How to Stop Supporting Your Adult Kids When You’re Retired
item.description: In trying to help grown children, parents can hurt their own retirement security. Here’s how to stop the flow of money.
item.dc:creator: Martha C. White
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I get deputized” to break the news to adult children that clients are ending financial support, said Malik Lee, a financial adviser.

item.title: Elon Musk’s 2018 Tesla Pay Deal Is Restored by Delaware Supreme Court
item.description: A state judge had invalidated the package, saying shareholders were not properly informed about it. Friday’s ruling cleared the plan, now worth $139 billion.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner, Peter Eavis and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Evan Vucci/Associated Press
item.media:description: Elon Musk had appealed a ruling by a Delaware judge who rejected Tesla’s pay package last year.

item.title: N.B.A. Tweaks Its Rules to Thwart Sports Betting Cheats
item.description: The basketball league will require teams to submit injury reports closer to tipoff, an attempt to close one source of inside information.
item.dc:creator: Tania Ganguli
item.media:credit: Kirby Lee/Imagn Images, via Reuters Connect
item.media:description: N.B.A. commissioner Adam Silver said this week that “we’re going to have to do whatever is necessary to protect our integrity.”

item.title: Real or Fake? There’s a War Over Christmas … Trees.
item.description: Tree farmers and the marketing group that supports them want more Americans to buy live-cut trees. A new Home Depot ad gave them holiday hope.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Artificial trees are taking a bite out of the Christmas tree farming industry.

item.title: Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern Try Making Their Case for a Merger
item.description: Regulators will decide whether a merger of Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern would improve shipment times or stifle competition. A decision is expected in 2027.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: If a merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern goes through, it will put about 40 percent of the nation’s rail freight in the hands of one railroad.

item.title: Trump Media Merger With Nuclear Fusion Firm Raises Ethics Questions
item.description: Trump Media plans to merge with a company developing nuclear fusion technology, putting the president’s financial interests in competition with other energy companies over which his administration holds sway.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s social media company said on Thursday that it had agreed to an all-stock merger with TAE Technologies, a fusion power company.

item.title: To Secure Money for Ukraine, Europe Had to Resort to a Messy Compromise
item.description: The European Union came up with an 11th-hour deal to help Ukraine, but the solution raised questions about the bloc’s decisiveness.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with a mortar, hidden from the sight of drones, near Kupiansk, in May. The European Union will funnel 90 billion euros’ worth of loans to Ukraine.

item.title: What Trump’s Push Into Nuclear Means for the Sector (and His Net Worth)
item.description: The president’s paper wealth soared on news that the company behind Truth Social has agreed to merge with a fusion start-up. But China is way ahead in the funding race to commercialize the technology.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount, Jordyn Holman and Grady McGregor
item.media:credit: Brendan Smialowski/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Trump saw his paper fortunes soar on the back of his namesake media and tech company forging a nuclear fusion deal.

item.title: When Did Everything Become ‘K-Shaped’?
item.description: What started as a term to describe the pandemic recovery has become a catchall in these anxious economic times.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Cristina Spanò

item.title: F.D.A. Turmoil Keeps Spotlight on Its Commissioner
item.description: The agency’s high-level turnover and conflicting policy decisions on drug oversight have fueled concerns about the leadership of Dr. Marty Makary.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Marty Makary, the F.D.A. commissioner, has faced intense criticism as the agency undergoes top-level turnover in critical areas like drug approvals.

item.title: Want to Know Where the Market Is Going? Don’t Trust This, or Any, Forecast.
item.description: Wall Street stock gurus are making predictions again. Our columnist got into the game with a number he doesn’t believe.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:credit: Peter Phobia

item.title: How Much More Can the U.S. Travel Industry Take?
item.description: Politics and border hassles have chased away foreign visitors, costing businesses billions. Some fear next year’s World Cup won’t be enough to bring tourists back.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A big drop in tourists from Canada has affected businesses in warm-weather U.S. destinations like Key West, Fla.

item.title: ‘A Singularly Turbulent Time’: Deeper Uncertainty in Store for Global Economy
item.description: A reordering of the rules of trade, set on top of transformational change in technology, demographics and climate, is remaking jobs, politics and lives.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Linh Pham para The New York Times
item.media:description: Una fábrica de muebles en Vietnam. Las exportaciones chinas se están disparando no solo hacia Europa, sino también hacia el Sudeste Asiático.

item.title: Bank of Japan Raises Interest Rates to Highest Level in 30 Years
item.description: The Bank of Japan moved to slow inflation as the prime minister is borrowing more to fund an ambitious effort to build up industry and support households.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Greg Baker/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The rate increase is widely viewed as an attempt to ultimately help cool inflation and give wages a chance to keep up.

item.title: TikTok Signs Agreements With Investors in Step Toward Avoiding a U.S. Ban
item.description: The Chinese-owned video app formalized commitments from the software giant Oracle and two investment firms as part of a deal to keep operating in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Hollie Adams/Reuters
item.media:description: Investment agreements bring TikTok, one of the country’s most popular social media apps, closer to resolving years of questions about its future.

item.title: Nike’s Struggles Continue, but Turnaround Plan May Be Working
item.description: Quarterly sales rose slightly for the world’s largest footwear company despite weak results in China and with its Converse brand.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski/Reuters
item.media:description: Nike is among the retailers affected by tariffs this year.

item.title: John E. Olson, Analyst Fired for Enron Skepticism, Dies at 83
item.description: Working for Merrill Lynch, he refused to recommend the energy trading company. His employer pushed him out, but his stand made him a hero.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Trump Administration Tries to Stop Some Immigrants From Driving Trucks
item.description: The Transportation Department said the new rules were intended to make roads safer, but there’s no data to suggest that immigrants cause more truck accidents.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Mikayla Whitmore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucking has long attracted immigrants hoping to earn a potentially substantial wage soon after arriving in the United States.

item.title: Democratic Lawmakers Request Review of Howard Lutnick’s Possible Conflicts
item.description: Lawmakers in the House and the Senate asked a government watchdog to determine if Howard Lutnick is following ethics guidelines in promoting data centers that benefit his family’s businesses.
item.dc:creator: Michael Rothfeld and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Democratic lawmakers in the Senate and House have asked the inspector general to examine the intersection between Mr. Lutnick’s actions and the work of his former companies.

item.title: Massachusetts Battery Start-Up to List on Stock Exchange
item.description: Factorial, the start-up, said the listing would provide money that would help it bring new solid-state batteries to market as soon as 2027.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Siyu Huang is the chief executive of Factorial.

item.title: Trump Media to Merge With TAE Technologies, a Nuclear Fusion Firm, in a $6 Billion Deal
item.description: Trump Media & Technology Group, the social media and crypto company part owned by President Trump, said it would help develop a “utility-scale fusion power plant.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein, Jonathan Wolfe and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Yuvraj Khanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trump Media & Technology Group is the parent company of Truth Social, a social media platform that has struggled to gain widespread traction.

item.title: Why the Affordability Crisis Is Likely to Stalk Trump
item.description: The president promoted his economic accomplishments in a defiant address. But some voters are feeling the pinch of stubborn inflation and a cooling labor market.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump went on the offensive in a prime time address on Wednesday night, seeking to reframe the discussion around America’s affordability crunch.

item.title: Lovable, a Start-Up That Makes Anyone a Coder, Raises $330 Million
item.description: The Swedish company is now valued at $6.6 billion, more than triple its $1.8 billion valuation set by investors in July.
item.dc:creator: Niko Gallogly

item.title: Interest Rate Cut and Slower Inflation Offer Britons a Reprieve
item.description: Britain’s central bank reduced interest rates to 3.75 percent, a move that was welcomed by the government, which has been looking to lower the high cost of living.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Justin Tallis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Bank of England in central London. The central bank has lowered interest rates six times in the past year and a half.

item.title: U.S. Inflation Slowed to 2.7% in November as Shutdown Distorts Data
item.description: Data collection issues skewed the latest Consumer Price Index report, economists warned, clouding the picture for the Federal Reserve as it also grapples with a cooling labor market.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
